title.narrative: COVID-19: inclusive education and digital environments

description.narrative: As an immediate response to the COVID-19 outbreak, the project aims to provide educational leaders, administrators and teachers with concrete knowledge and skills as well as appropriate tools and resources to make education more accessible and inclusive to all learners. A special attention will be placed on the application of the Open and Distance Learning as one of the most sustainable methods for overcoming the educational barriers faced by persons with disabilities during the emergency situations. The ODL is also considered to be a more sustainable method for overcoming the educational barriers in a long term. The inter-sectoral project will be implemented by CI, SHS, ED and IIEP.

title.narrative: Re-imagining Education for marginalized girls and boys during and post Covid-19 in Bosnia and Herzegovina

description.narrative: This joint programme proposal is an integral part of the UN Socio-economic Response Plan in BiH, which holistically addresses immediate and intermediate consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic and enables synergies of different sectors to achieve more inclusive and more resilient society. This proposal is designed to contribute in a straightforward and comprehensive way to minimising the immediate socio-economic consequences emerging due to educational disruption in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. The proposed interventions will also point at decreasing the immediate risks of dropping-out and having out-of-school children in case the regular education is disrupted.

title.narrative: Supporting emergency measures and recovery actions to tackle COVID-19 in the indigenous territories in the Amazon Region

description.narrative: The initiative supports the implementation of emergency measures to prevent COVID-19 transmission among indigenous peoples of the Amazon Region of Brazil by improving community health care support and by promoting culturally tailored health education, and will also support their economic resilience through the promotion of gender and human rights-responsive recovery actions.

title.narrative: Strengthening Education Sector Response to COVID-19 Pandemic in Mongolia

description.narrative: The UN joint project aims to support the Government of Mongolia to implement the national COVID-19 preparedness and response plan by focusing on critical education and health services delivery. The emergency response UN project will support immediate education sector interventions to address the school closures. The UN will assist and support the Ministry of Education (MECSS) to ensure continuity and accessibility of quality basic on-line education services for children, adolescences, and youth, including those with disabilities and from ethnic minorities, which was interrupted by COVID-19 pandemic. The UN project will be jointly implemented by WHO, UNESCO, UNICEF and UNFPA.

title.narrative: UN COVID-19 MPTF: Immediate UN Response for coherent safeguarding the livelihoods of people made most vulnerable by COVID-19 in Nepal

description.narrative: In response to the impact of COVID-19, the project aims to safeguard peoples' livelihoods through immediate employment generation and financial security of informal sector workers, mostly women, including internal migrants and migrant workers returning from abroad, and women's cooperatives. In addition, the project also envisages to design, develop, and roll-out cash for work for vulnerable community members, including migrants, women, Dalits, and workers in the tourism sector and to provide technical assistance to the planning, design and roll-out of targeted short-term vocational and skill training. The project is being implemented by UNESCO, along with UNDP, ILO and IOM.

title.narrative: Inclusive Economic Recovery through Sustainable Enterprises in the Informal Economies of Fiji, Palau, Tonga and Vanuatu

description.narrative: A Joint UN project with a focus on strengthening the informal economy, including the cultural and creative industries. The intervention addresses unemployment and aims to support sustainable enterprises in the informal sub-sectors following the impact of COVID-19. The local informal creative industries, mostly operating as micro home-based enterprises, have been particularly affected by the contraction of the tourism sector. The project will aim to strengthen the cultural industries, and capitalize on local creative talent through specialized skills transfer, market linkages, and by addressing pre-existing challenges in the structure and mechanisms of the informal economy.

title.narrative: Support the development of a national policy or projects to leverage ICT to achieve SDG4 in Chile

description.narrative: Chile has been promoting ICT in education from the early '90s, and technologies are widely available and used in public schools across the country. However, the crisis of COVID-19 has exposed persisting gaps in terms of access to technology, connectivity, educational resources, and teaching skills to leverage ICT to achieve SDG4 in Chile. Addressing these issues will require a long-term vision and appropriate strategies to organize efforts, allocate resources, and set priorities aligned to education development plans. Within this context, the project aims to lay the foundations for developing, implementing, monitoring and assessing a national policy on ICT in Education in Chile.

title.narrative: Safeguarding of Intangible Cultural Heritage in the Caribbean in the face of COVID-19

description.narrative: Following preparation and release of the global UNESCO report 'Living heritage in the face of COVI-19' and its three recommendations with associated safeguarding actions to orient the efforts of governments, civil society, the private sector and bearers to strengthen the safeguarding of living heritage during the pandemic as well as in the COVID-19 recovery phase, the activity will help the communities of Barbados, Jamaica, Sint Maarten and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines to safeguard their living heritage.

title.narrative: Digitization of the intangible cultural heritage elements of communities of Bosnia and Herzegovina

description.narrative: The proposed project is to support the ongoing initiative to digitize elements of living heritage practiced in Bosnia and Herzegovina, being implemented by the NGOs familiar with the 2003 Convention. Beneficiary communities will be i) sensitized on the importance of intangible cultural heritage safeguarding and they will also receive support for ii) identifying elements of their intangible cultural heritage and iii) documenting them with the use of digital technology. Particular attention will be paid for understanding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the safeguarding of living heritage among these communities and their aspirations and needs for recovery and preparedness.

title.narrative: Promoting the Safeguarding of Intangible Cultural Heritage and South-South Cooperation in Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela

description.narrative: Regarding the four States Parties of the cluster, all of them submitted their periodic reports due in march 2021. The Quito Office focused on assisting Bolivia, due to the recent creation of the Ministry of Cultures, Decolonization and Depatriarchalization. In the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, in 2020 the Quito Office organized four webinars focussed on women and ICH, in order to better mainstream gender issues in ICH discussions. In june 2021, the Quito Office launched a study on the impact of COVID-19 on ICH, with a focus on developing recommendations regarding ICH for economic recovery of vulnerable communities.

title.narrative: Inclusive education for out of school children and youth in Central America

description.narrative: Despite considerable progress in access to and participation in education, in 2017 there were still 5 million children and adolescents who did not attend school in Central America due to a variety of reasons. Given the specific context of COVID that affected the education systems concerning most vulnerable populations in Central America, UNESCO will provide technical assistance to Ministries of Education in a proposal of monitoring, evaluation and transition post covid adjusted for each country with focus on excludes populations.

title.narrative: Reinforcing policies for community participation in World Heritage sites in the cluster

description.narrative: The main activity was reoriented to tackle the new challenges brought by the COVID-19 pandemic as regards the livelihoods of surrounding communities. The activity was launched on mid-june 2021, and sites to be included in the study are being selected with States Parties. Also, and international consultant has been hired to develop a toolkit on World Heritage Education, adapted to the new reality brought by the pandemic and focused on youth participation in the protection of the OUV of the sites.

title.narrative: Support pour la mise en oeuvre de la Convention de 1972 en Haïti: "Ripos Nò Korona - PNH CSSR sans Covid-19"

description.narrative: Cette activité a pour but de soutenir la mise en œuvre de la Convention de 1972 en Haïti, en étroite collaboration avec le Centre du patrimoine mondial, conformément aux décisions du Comité du Patrimoine mondial et selon les priorités du Plan d'action du Patrimoine mondial en Amérique latine et les Caraïbes. Une attention particulière sera consacrée à l'association des communautés dans la gestion du Patrimoine mondial et à la sensibilisation du grand public d'Haïti, des femmes et des hommes issus de la société civile, des communautés locales, des jeunes, D'une manière générale l'activité facilitera l'intégration, la diversité culturelle et le respect de l'environnement dans l'élaboration des politiques publiques au développement.

description.narrative: Through this project IFAP will partner with the UNESCO Institute for Information Technologies in Education, located in Moscow, to train trainers from teacher training institutions in nine countries on digital media and information literacy (MIL) education.

title.narrative: Caribbean Artificial Intelligence Initiative in the context COVID-19

description.narrative: This project will benefit Caribbean Small Island Developing States (SIDS) by providing capacity building webinars on Artificial Intelligence (AI) in the context of the COVID-19 crisis. Implemented by UNESCO Kingston Office in partnership with the Broadcasting Commission of Jamaica, the project aims to build the capacity of participants to cope with the COVID-19 crisis. The webinars will especially consider the Caribbean context and discuss how to harness the potential of AI to accelerate sustainable development in Small Island Developing States (SIDS).

title.narrative: CapED Programme - Education Response to the COVID-19 crisis

description.narrative: The CapED Programme is an extrabudgetary programme created in 2003 based on the understanding that education reforms will not be effective if countries lack the capacities to make them operational. With an overarching capacity development approach, CapED seeks to improve the quality of education and increase learning opportunities, especially for girls and women and disadvantaged population groups. Under "Education Response to the COVID-19 crisis", CapED will address urgent needs to respond to school closures and ensure continuity of learning through distance-learning modalities and crisis-sensitive, contingency planning.

title.narrative: Strengthening Media Development and Freedom of Expression in Cambodia

description.narrative: Recognizing freedom of expression, and its corollaries of freedom of information and media freedom, as fundamental human rights and critical pillars to democracy, this project aims to foster a safe, free, pluralistic and independent media environment conducive to greater freedom of expression in Cambodia. The project aims at strengthening the media sector while addressing the urgent needs derived from the Covid-19 pandemic, including ensuring greater access to critical information, advocating for higher standards in ethical reporting, promoting investigative journalism and strengthening the public's Media and Information Literacy competencies.

title.narrative: Strengthening the responsiveness, agility and resilience of TVET institutions in the post-COVID-19 (December 2020 - June 2021) era

description.narrative: The project is conceived to help alleviate the immediate, mid- and long-term effects of the global COVID-19 crisis to learning and employment by providing TVET institutions and training providers with opportunities to mitigate the impact of the pandemic and sustaining their efforts in curbing the long-term effect of the pandemic. TVET Institutions will be supported in managing relevant and immediate skill development programmes , and in raising their institutional capacity to deliver new digital services and to adopt developed tools that are useful in establishing institutional resilience in the post-COVID-19 era.

title.narrative: Promoting sustainable tourism and private sector engagement for inclusive community development in response to the COVID-19 crisis

description.narrative: The project will address some of the immediate socio-economic impacts of COVID-19 on tourism and heritage, accelerating the recovery to protect livelihoods and transform the sectors to become more inclusive and sustainable. The project will focus on engaging the tourism private sector to create incentives to boost competitiveness based on sustainable practices by providing training and capacity building for key stakeholders. It will invest in cultural heritage preservation while creating short term job opportunities by utilizing culture and heritage as a source of resilience.

title.narrative: Global Education Coalition response to Latin America and the Caribbean Region

description.narrative: It aims to support UNESCO's Global Education Coalition, the development of quality distance education and teacher training in LAC, as well as offering training for migrants and refugees: 1) Capacity development of teacher trainers, teachers and education leaders on digital skills and blended learning solutions in 20 Caribbean countries; 2) Distance Learning and training strategies for migrants and refugees in Peru; and 3) strengthening global, regional and sub-regional coordination and cooperation in the education responses to COVID-19, tapping into the resources offered by GEC.

title.narrative: Education Response to COVID-19 in Advancing the National Educational Broadcasting System to Ensure the Continuity of Learning in Basic Science Education for All in Timor-Leste

description.narrative: As a post-project of Cycle 3 of Basic Education for Mathematics and Science in Timor-Leste (526TIM1000 from 14 February 2014 to 30 May, 2018) to support Timor-Leste Ministry of Education, Youth, and Sport (TL-MoEYS), this project supports Basic Education School-aged children during and post- COVID-19 for their continuity of learning Science through the National Educational Broadcasting System (EBS) enabling them to access to Free and Quality Education covering all 13 Districts across the country.

title.narrative: Post COVID-19 World Heritage Site Management: Integration of Conservation, Tourism and Local Livelihood Strategies at World Heritage Sites

description.narrative: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, national lockdowns and global travel restrictions led to the closure of many heritage sites around the world, resulting in socio-economic impacts, disruption of community life in and around properties, and in many cases the aggravation of poverty. Through a series of pilot cases at World Heritage properties in four regions of the world, this project proposes an overall approach, strategies and capacity building for site management at World Heritage properties in response to COVID-19, integrating conservation, with a place-based sustainable development approach supporting local livelihood opportunities along with enhanced digital presence and sustainable tourism.

title.narrative: JICA Phase 3

description.narrative: In order to understand best approaches to improve the teaching and learning environments and enhance learning opportunities in Syria, the programme aims at enhancing the teaching and learning environment in basic education, including training of education personnel and implementation of School Improvement Plan. Furthermore, the programme will provide a Catch-up Programme for Syrian youth at risk of dropping out of school and those who have returned to school after many years of absence due to conflict. The Catch-up Programme directly responds to the learning loss from the COVID-19 outbreak.

title.narrative: Reviving Mosul and Basra Old Cities_Phase Two

description.narrative: This project was prepared as a response to Covid-19 and its socio-economic impact in Iraq. The overall objective of this project is to contribute to economic recovery as well as to social cohesion through creation of decent jobs in re-construction of historical urban centres of Mosul and Basra as well as support to Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) active in various sectors and the cultural and creative industries through a financing mechanism. It will build up on the ongoing activities in both cities implemented by UNESCO and IOM in order to provide a quick response to the pandemic and ensure immediate impact on local economies.

title.narrative: Support for social stability through education and vocational training for out-of-school youths following the security and health crises in the Sahel and eastern regions of Burkina Faso

description.narrative: The main objective of the project is to promote stability in the eastern and Sahel regions of Burkina Faso by providing children of school going age and young people with skills for employment, enhanced capacities to deal with violent extremism, and committed to peace and citizenship through education and vocational training. The activities to be carried out aim to train 150 young people, aged 18 to 24 years old, who dropped out of school. Cross-cutting aspects of this project is the acquisition of knowledge and life skills in terms of promoting peace, citizenship and the fight against certain pandemics such as COVID-19 for both students in vocational training and in bridging centers

title.narrative: Mitigating the impact of COVID-19 on Education through distance learning in Iraq

description.narrative: To respond to the COVID-19 crisis and the closure of schools since the end of February 2020, UNESCO is building upon the support previously provided to the TV channel, by assisting the MoE's TV to complete the production of television based lectures for full all the subjects for grades 1 - 6 and ALP. The overall objective of this project is to mitigate the disruption to learning caused by the COVID-19 crisis by maximizing access to distance learning opportunities for all school age learners across the country through the provision of the continued support to the Federal Ministry of Education TV channel.

title.narrative: Developing Digital skills and Education for Sustainable Development through Distance Learning in Palestine - Phase I

description.narrative: COVID-19 affected education in Palestine as teachers and students moved to online teaching and learning and youth lost job opportunities. It is important to mitigate the impact on education and human resource development by providing digital and transversal skills for sustainable development through distance education platforms and TVET. UNESCO's project will target 300 of the most vulnerable and most affected schools in the West Bank and Gaza Strip during its pilot phase. This will ensure MoE will be capable of developing and uploading online lessons to all grades in Palestine and providing training in soft and digital skills for TVET students in different areas such as WBL.

title.narrative: Lifelines to Learning: Towards an International Declaration on Connectivity for Education

description.narrative: Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, the right to education has become-at the global level-dependent on connectivity, especially internet access. The pandemic forced policy makers, teachers, parents and learners to attempt actions to leverage connectivity for learning at a speed and scale without precedent. The pandemic has revealed the need to rethink connectivity for learning in a transformed global educational landscape. This initiative will facilitate the production and endorsement of an International Declaration on Connectivity for Education, and will involve research and consultation.

title.narrative: L'Éducation Culturelle et Valeur Sociétale pour la Paix et un Environnement Sain au Mali

description.narrative: The project is part of the "peace and reconciliation agreement in Mali" resulting from the Algiers process in which the signatory parties express their attachment to the recognition and promotion of cultural diversity. The general objective of the project is to support the Government of Mali through cultural actors and the education system in the exploitation and promotion of knowledge and know-how, the revitalization of the mechanisms of traditional crisis management and provide significant support in its fight against Covid-19. It will build on the country's values ??with the aim of finding a healthy environment, and lasting peace and social cohesion.

title.narrative: Supporting SDG 4 in the Arab Region Under COVID-19 Conditions

description.narrative: Within the leadership role of UNESCO for SDG 4 in the Arab States, the partnership with OSF will unpack the SDG 4 agenda through the following interventions: 1) conduct multiple webinars on specific topics within education that reflects the current context and challenges related to e-learning, 2) conduct a research on education financing that reflects the current trends and challenges, 3) develop guidance on contextualized SDG 4 indicators, and 4) deliver capacity building webinars on the indicator addressed under (3).

title.narrative: Strengthening the resilience of the culture sectors of Ethiopia, Mali, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and Benin in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic

description.narrative: In the framework of the ALIPH COVID-19 Action Plan, the project aims to strengthen the resilience of the culture sectors of Ethiopia, Mali, the DRC, and Benin in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. In Ethiopia, the project will provide personal protective equipment and signage for 9 WH properties and 22 museums. In Mali, the project will implement the annual re-plastering ceremony at the WH property of 'Timbuktu'. In the DRC, the project will regenerate income-earning activities for the communities of the WH property of the 'Virunga National Park'. In Benin, the project will digitalize the museum collections and site components of the WH property of the 'Royal Palaces of Abomey'.

title.narrative: PROJET GPE DE RIPOSTE D'URGENCE CONTRE LA COVID-19 DANS L'ENSEIGNEMENT DE BASE AU CAMEROUN

description.narrative: Le projet s'inscrit dans le cadre de la mise en œuvre des activités du don du GPE octroyé au Cameroun d'un montant de 11 millions de $US pour l'appui à la mise en œuvre du Plan National de riposte contre l'impact de la COVID-19 dans le secteur de l'éducation et de la formation. Il vise à assurer la continuité de l'enseignement de base pour les élèves du public affectés par la crise de la COVID-19, préparer la réouverture des établissements scolaires et l'organisation des cours dans un environnement sanitaire sûr et protecteur et renforcer la résilience du système éducatif face aux crises

title.narrative: Burkina Faso et Mali: Création d’emplois équitables et développement durable de microentreprises dans les chaines de valeur liées au secteur du « lifestyle »

description.narrative: Le projet a pour but de contribuer au développement économique et à l’emploi dans le secteur artisanal au Burkina Faso et au Mali et ainsi réduire la pression migratoire au sein de ces pays, en luttant contre les causes profondes des phénomènes de déstabilisation et ce, en offrant des possibilités de formation et en favorisant la création d’emplois dignes, durables et équitablement rémunérés respectant les normes du Fair Labour Association (FLA - Association pour le Travail Equitable en français). Au sein de l'International Trade Centre (ITC), le projet sera mis en place par l'équipe de l’Ethical Fashion Initiative (EFI) qui a pour but de contribuer à la réduction de la pauvreté en permettant à des artisans marginalisés de pays en voie de développement de s’insérer dans le marché international du « lifestyle » qui comprend, la mode, la décoration intérieur, l’ameublement et les industries créatives. EFI a lancé un projet de promotion à l’international du tissage artisanal du coton au Burkina Faso et au Mali de 2013 à 2016 et ce projet a obtenu de très bons résultats. Le projet présenté ici constitue la Phase II de l’intervention de EFI dans la chaine de valeur du tissage. Ce projet a pour but d’étendre significativement le nombre de bénéficiaires, en contribuant à la création et la stabilisation de 4650 emplois justement rémunérés et durables au Burkina Faso et au Mali, mais surtout d’adresser la problématique de l’émigration en ayant comme populations cibles les personnes susceptibles de migrer (en particulier les jeunes), les migrants de retour dans leurs pays d’origine après expulsion et des demandeurs d’asile en Europe potentiellement candidats aux programmes de Retours Volontaires Assistés (RVA). Le projet interviendra tout au long de la chaine de valeur du tissage artisanal, de l’égrenage du coton à la transformation des tissus en produits finis. Il apportera des débouchées dans le secteur du « lifestyle » qui comprend la mode mais aussi l’aménagement et la décoration d’intérieur. Au Burkina Faso le projet opère à travers une entreprise sociale dénommée Groupement d’Intérêt Economique « Commerce et Artisanat pour le Bien-Être Social », GIE CABES en abrégé Au Mali le Projet a du integrer la recrudescence des problèmes sécuritaires , des violences intracommunautaires et des personnes déplacées. Une stratégie de decentralisation a été necessaire à travers l’activation d’atelier-pilote incubateurs d’inclusion de micro-entrepreneur/artisan auto-employé start up et de la moyenne entreprise selon une dimension regionale/cluster et par chaine de valeur à avantage compétitif liées à l’E-Commerce . Une cooperative consortium export/entreprise sociale interface unique est prévue en option exit strategy . Les entreprises sociales contextualisent le modèle d’intervention standard de EFI à travers le repérage, l’identification et l’organisation et la délivrance de l’assistance technique spécialisée à ces micro et très petites entreprises indépendantes déjà constituées, avec des artisans talentueux (mais assez souvent informelles et inconnues des autorités fiscales), afin de mettre en commun leurs faibles moyens, leur permettre de réduire leurs charges, de développer une offre complète, crédible et de qualité pour les acheteurs, régionaux, internationaux et ainsi d’accroitre leurs revenus issus des exportations. La nouvelle Pandémie du COVID-19 a comporté des impacts déjà négatifs, donc des ajustements budgétaires force majeure sont necéssaires, pour réorienter et adapter de nouvelles innovations dans les modalités de l’assistance technique, et dans les outils de connexion durables aux marchés au niveau national, regional et international. Le Donateur accordera une extension de 12 mois supplementaires pour les mesures attenuant la reprise de la crise économique et sociale, et le rallentissement des echanges commerciaux.

reporting-org.narrative: International Trade Centre (ITC)

title.narrative: Support Trade Negotiations

description.narrative: This project will contribute to building conducive investment environment in targeted countries including through a PPD approach, advisory services and capacity building. In 2020, the following outcomes were achieved:* WTO Accession – TPR process: With the support of ITC, the Ministry of Investment and Foreign Trade of Uzbekistan was able (i) to notify to the WTO Secretariat its initial offers for liberalization of trade in goods and services; and (ii) to draft and share with the WTO Secretariat answers to questions produced by the WTO Members. This joint support contributed to the holding of the 4th Working Party Meeting in July 2020.In addition, Tajikistan preparation for its first Trade Policy Review was further supported through ITC technical advices; Through the joint support of ITC and other international organizations, seven African countries that are currently acceding to the WTO were enable to share information and experience in relation to their respective negotiations as well as prepare their accession strategy in sync with the AfCFTA negotiations. This support aimed at enhancing the representation and voice of developing countries in the WTO Secretariat (10.6 and 16.8) and will contribute in expending the universal, rule based, open and non-discriminatory multilateral trading system (17.10). WTO accession, and the policy and regulatory reforms stemming from that process, contribute to establish a conducive policy environment fostering investment, industrial diversification and value addition. In addition, ITC's intervention aimed at forging a consensus among public and private sector together on the WTO accession and the domestic policy reforms it implies. As such, it contributes to ensure inclusive public private consultation for policy formulation purpose (17.17);* Regional integration: AfCFTA and Regional integration in Africa Business representatives of The Gambia were better equipped to engage with negotiators and advocate for their views throughout the Services AfCFTA negotiations/implementation as a result of ITC’s advisory services, national public private dialogue/training and AfCFTA customized business friendly guides. The later were accessible for all stakeholders beyond The Gambia. This support, which aimed at forging a consensus among public and private sector together on the AfCFTA negotiations and implementation, is a contribution to ensure inclusive public private consultation for policy formulation purpose (17.17). *Customized trade policy related advisory services and publications: In 2020, the understanding of the business opportunities and challenges - including those related to the COVID 19 pandemic - stemming from trade policy issues, regulatory reforms and/or trade negotiations has been supported across countries through the production of analytical papers, the dissemination of 862 copies of technical publications (e.g. Indian DFQF scheme), the provision of advisory services and the training of representatives from the private/public sectors with a view to inform and contribute to national and or regional consensus for policy/regulatory reforms/trade related negotiations (17.17). CII expressed satisfaction to the services provided by ITC and reported that 52 participants who attended the ITC webinar dedicated to COVID 19 was very useful and strategic.* Leveraging: In 2020, this project contributed to widen or deepen ITC's intervention in relation to trade negotiations. Further intervention in Uzbekistan were instrumental in leveraging a new full fledge EU funded project in Uzbekistan (Tentative budget allocation: USD 5 million). Expertise developed under this project also was instrumental in leveraging new projects in Iraq (WTO accession component: € 4.5 million), CEFTA (Negotiations on services liberalization. Tentative budget: USD 800 000), Thailand (Competition and Public Procurement. Tentative budget: USD 1 Million), Malaysia (negotiations with the EU. Tentative budget: USD 1 million) Nepal (addressing NTMs. Tentative budget: USD 800 000) and Comoros (policy/regulatory reforms for export competitiveness). in 2021, the following specific intervention will be carried out: Multilateral/ WTO accession: Awareness raising workshops/training/capacity building workshops to enhance technical skills of private sector on the implications of WTO Accessions in 5 countries in partnership with the WTO Secretariat. Provision of advisory services in support of specific countries' WTO accession process (depending on the pace of the negotiations) and/or Trade Policy Reviews processes.* Regional integration: Awareness raising workshops/training/capacity building workshops to enhance technical skills of private sector on the implications of the African Continental Free Trade Agreement and what the private sector ought to do in the context of its negotiations. Advisory services will be provided to a number of countries/regions (e.g. continuing support to The Gambia) in order to assist them in formulating their negotiating positions in relation to the different chapters of the AfCFTA negotiations or assist them in the early implementation. Organize Public Private Dialogues in support of specific countries/subregions' AfCFTA negotiations process (depending on the pace of the negotiations)* Policy/regulatory related analytical papers on emerging issues and/or strategic areas such as Trade policy/regulations and digital/green economy; Investment/services; including in the African context will be produced with a view to define new areas for TFPB intervention/services.* Leveraging: the expertise/materials developed under this project will be leveraged to develop and implement new donors funded intervention featuring a trade policy component.

reporting-org.narrative: International Trade Centre (ITC)

title.narrative: Fast Tracking Digital Entrepreneurship in Africa - Phase 1

description.narrative:
The “Fast Tracking Digital Entrepreneurship in Africa” project was launched in November 2019 and rolled out in seven countries: Benin, Côte d’Ivoire, Ethiopia, Mali, Rwanda, Tanzania and Zambia. Its pilot phase will end on 31 December 2021, with a total budget of 1 M USD.
The project aims to support digital entrepreneurs and tech startups in sub-Saharan Africa with online and onsite training, advisory and coaching focused on building digital and business skills as well as domestic, regional & international business generation and investment promotion. The project also engages with the business support organisations, in particular tech hubs, and government to strengthen local tech ecosystems.
Results as of Q2 2020 are detailed below: Impact: Fast track the growth and internationalization of African tech and the creation of value-added jobs Impact level information on jobs created will be gathered in December 2020. The project is contributing to SDG 4 “Quality education - TARGET 4.4: Ensure youth and adults have relevant skills for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship” and 5 “Gender equality - TARGET 5.b: Enhance use of enabling technology to promote the empowerment of women”. The project will also report on SDG 8 - Decent Work. The team will start monitoring SDG 9 on innovation, as Covid-19 is possibly an important catalyst for digitization and sustainability.
Outcome: The competitiveness of the tech sector is increased in partner countries Since mid-March 2020, we have been in regular contact with FastTrackTech beneficiaries to measure the impact of Covid 19 on their businesses. Most planned B2B activities were cancelled or postponed since traveling and public gatherings are restricted. 2020 Work Plans have been reviewed to adapt to the current situation, which will seriously impact our capacity to generate business and investment opportunities for our beneficiaries.
Output 1: Ecosystem Development 1.1. Undertake ecosystem mapping in two pilot countries to identify key players and sector needs The Tech Entrepreneurship Ecosystem Mapping Report (Zambia) has been finalised in April 2020. ZICTA, The Zambia Information and Communications Technology Authority, uploaded it to their website : https://www.zicta.zm/Downloads/ecosystem.pdf. The report received very positive feedback from the stakeholders involved in its design, including from the Ministry of Commerce, Trade and Industry (MCTI). Due to the Covid19 crisis we have not been able to present the recommendations in the form of a physical meeting or event. We are talking to ZICTA and MCTI how we, together with other ecosystem players, can implement and drive the recommendations. Two articles on the Ecosystem Mapping were published. One on the ITC website: http://www.intracen.org/news/Coordination-is-crucial-for-Zambias-tech-start-up-ecosystem-study-find and one in the Startup Journal Africa. 1.2. Organise private-public tech sector coordination dialogues to influence sector regulation and policies Discussions in Benin and Côte d’Ivoire to contribute to the finalisation of the local startup acts are on hold due to Covid19.
Output 2: Next-generation of trade-support institutions (tech hubs) are scaled up and networked 2.1. Identify and engage potential partner tech hubs The following 18 tech hubs have been identified and engaged: ● Benin: Etrilabs, Sèmè City ● Côte d’Ivoire: Incub'Ivoir, SeedSpace, BabyLab ● Ethiopia: iceaddis, icoglab, AccelerateEthiopia ● Mali: Donilab, Bamako Incubateur ● Rwanda: 250Startups, ICT Chamber ● Tanzania: Ennovate, Sahara Accelerator, Seedspace Dar es Salaam ● Zambia: Bongohive, Jacaranda Hub The project team is organising joint activities such as the Business Growth and Build Early Traction coachings with Accelerated Ethiopia, the Digital Marketing Webinar with BongoHive Zambia, the Effective Business Practices mentoring by Incub’Ivoire in Côte d'Ivoire and the Investment readiness coaching with 250Startups Rwanda. The project also commissioned a podcast series from Bongohive for the second half of 2020. In Tanzania, FastTrackTech partnered with Ennovate Hub, a local incubator, to organise a hackathon – the Covid 19 Innovation Challenge, jointly with GIZ. The hackathon took place in June. The hub will offer business development support to the local FastTrackTech startups. Foodsasa and A-Trader completed the needs assessment and had an onboarding call with Ennovate Hub at the end of June. The support includes a mentorship plan for each startup, based on the needs assessment. The general business development sessions will start in July and one-on-one sessions with each startup will take place at the end of July. In Mali, discussions have been initiated by the Agence des Technologies de l'Information et de la Communication (AGETIC) which is particularly interested in co-organising training events with #FastTrackTech and a roundtable with the different institutions supporting the Information Technology sector. A full proposal will be submitted for validation. 2.2. Build capacity through tailored online and on-site training & advisory Discussions are ongoing with Afric’Innov and the Word Bank to organise a regional training involving our West African tech hubs in Bamako once travel is possible again. Alternatively, the training will take place online in Q3. Due to COVID19, the capacity building planned to benefit the hubs also now focuses on helping them to provide a response to the crisis. Sèmè City Open Park (Bénin), Make 3D Ltd (in the Gambia, thanks to synergies with ITC’s YEP project), Baby Lab (Côte d’Ivoire) and Doni Fab (Mali), four fab labs with 3D printing facilities are being connected to increase regional cooperation around initiatives to 3D print medical equipment in the context of Covid-19. Several online meetings have already taken place and the communication is ongoing. The fab labs, which encountered production-related challenges, are able to exchange on good processes & supplies. Baby Lab and Doni Fab are being supported financially through the project. Moreover, #FastTrackTech launched a call for supported tech hubs to benefit from funding up to 2000 USD subject to validation of their needs. Incub’Ivoire, a local incubator from Côte d’Ivoire, will be subsidized to deliver general support to local FastTrackTech startups as a contribution to the development of the local ecosystem. 2.3. Facilitate the establishment of national umbrella tech-hub consortia for stronger advocacy impact in advanced ecosystems This is not foreseen at this stage due to the reduced budget in 2020.
Output 3: Startups and digital entrepreneurs are equipped with essential business and digital skills Due to the Covid-19 pandemic and the related restrictions, on-site training and coaching activities were shifted in late March to digital platforms. The level of engagement of our beneficiaries has been high in the beginning of the crisis. However, we lately experienced the start of a webinar fatigue due to the high number of online activities they are exposed to. 3.1. Build #360Diagnostics tool focused on Startup Internationalisation ITC’s suite of #360Diagnostics tools is being completed with a specific module on startup internationalisation. A first draft of the related handbook was completed in June. The tool will be ready for testing before the end of Q3. The migration of the other tools to the online platform 360diagnostics.intracen.org has been seriously delayed because of the impact of the pandemic on our IT company based in Bangladesh. Nevertheless, we are making progress. 3.2 Engage, assess and segment tech startups All the startups from the 7 beneficiary countries were assessed with the #360Diagnostic Tool. There are now 130+ startups assessed and 121 categorized under FastTrackTech. In Q1 2020, 33 startups were assessed in Rwanda and Tanzania, including 5 women. 27 were retained for the project: 13 Growth and 14 Entrepreneurship. 3 assessment sessions took place. In Rwanda, the call for applications was promoted by 250Startups and Klab, two leading tech hubs in Kigali. A total of 23 applications were received. Applicants were assessed during the kick-off mission in Kigali in February 2020. 15 startups were selected: 5 under Growth and 10 under Entrepreneurship. In addition,the three most advanced start-ups (all youth, no women) were assessed with the newly developed #360Diagnostics Due Diligence tool that focuses on investment readiness. In Tanzania, the last FastTrackTech country to be engaged, the mobilisation campaign was entirely remote. No kick-off mission could be organised due to the Covid19 outbreak. Out of the 15 startups that applied, 12 startups including 1 women-led were assessed online using the #360Diagnostics maturity check tool. All 12 were retained for the project (8 Growth, 4 Entrepreneurship). 3.3 Equip individual digital entrepreneurs with marketable digital skills In Q1, 94 digital entrepreneurs were trained and/or advised overall including 35 women and 64 youth. The training activities were conducted through webinars due to the COVID19 restrictions. The English speaking webinars were also open to Gambian tech entrepreneurs that are YEP beneficiaires (figures mentioned in the present report exclude YEP beneficiaires). The Freelancer component, which was entirely online in its first phase, resulted in a large pipeline of interested candidates mobilized in Tanzania, Rwanda and Ethiopia. Unfortunately, the reduced funding resulted in few interactions with too many participants. As a resulted, few were completing the online courses. The second phase will be focused on Tanzania only and rely more on human interactions. Initially planned to start in April, due to Covid, it was postponed to June. A partnership with Ennovate in Dar EsSalam foresees the organisation of weekly meet-ups with a local mentor. Activities are resuming in July. 3.4 Train and advise tech startup founders with business skills Overall, 103 startup founders and staff, including 19 women and 75 youths, were trained or coached since the beginning of the year. (In Q1, 15 startups founders and staff were trained and/or advised overall including 1 women and 11 youth. In Q2, 88 startups founders and staff were coached and/or advised overall including 18 women and 64 youth.)
Output 4: Beneficiary startups and digital entrepreneurs are exposed to and matched with business & investment opportunities 4.1. Design marketing materials to promote partner ecosystems and tech startups The FastTrackTech web pages under the corporate website are online and being expanded with profiles of the supported startups and contents on tools in both French and English: www.intracen.org/e-Trade-for-Impact/Fast-Tracking-Digital-Entrepreneurship-in-Africa/ The project is also referenced under the eTrade4All platform since the beginning of the year: https://etradeforall.org/development-solution/itc-fast-tracking-digital-entrepreneurship-in-africa/?main-policy=legal-regulatory-frameworks Two private #FastTrackTech Facebook Groups have been set up, one for the French-speaking countries and one for the English-speaking countries, which are being used in the framework of a 2020 Social Media Strategy with a related content calendar. Two editors are writing articles about our activities in French and English. 4.2. Identify and engage potential market partners and investors A dedicated #FastTrackTech project page is up and running on the global CrunchBase portal. 76 companies have so far been linked to the page. The goal is to have all companies under the project included by Q3. This will bring more visibility to both FastTrack Tech and to the companies added as CrunchBase is the leading destination for company insights from early stage startups to the Fortune 1000. In Côte d’Ivoire, in the context of the preparation of the UNCTAD e-commerce readiness report mission to Abidjan in early March 2020, ITC’s e-commerce team reached out to Growth startups Ahiwaaa by Afrik'apps, ETUDESK, MON ARTISAN for a case study on their operations. 4.3. Connect beneficiaries with potential clients and investors Due to Covid-19, several planned B2B events were cancelled: Mobile World Congress and 4YFN, Transform Africa Summit in Conakry, VivaTech, SIPEN and SLUSH. The trade fair “Benin Digital Tour” that was supposed to take place late March in Cotonou and late April in Abidjan was cancelled due to Covid-19 outbreak. Likewise, the joint event on Open Innovation organised with the Chamber of Commerce postponed. In February, #FastTrackTech startups exhibited at Bamako Digital Days in Mali. The booth was visited by the Prime Minister of Mali and the Minister of Digital Economy. Two #FastTrackTech women-led start-ups, So-Dokotoro and Denko Kunafoni, won start-up challenges and the prize for the best female digital start-up. So-dokotoro raised 5 Million FCFA (8225 USD) that they attributed to the project because of the exposure given to their venture (C3/C4). The team is exploring innovative ways to provide the startups with access to new customers. In July, we will be partnering with La Foire Virtuelle, an innovative concept replacing physical fairs in times of social distancing through an online store where the exhibitors can sell their products. The fair is planned from 1 to 31 July 2020. The ITC FastTrackTech country leads took part two sessions of the CIO MAG Econf #Challenge, the first one with the minister for digitalisation of Benin, Madame Aurélie ADAM SOULE ZOUMAROU. She presented the #FastTrackTech project activities. Sedric Degbo, CEO of Rema Medicals, a Beninese FastTrackTech startup, was showcased during the online conference, which was attended by 100+ participants. The second one hosted the Minister for the DIgital Economy of Côte d’Ivoire, the head of Fondation Jeunesse Numérique, as well as Etudesk and Legafrik, two beneficiary startups. The e-conference was attended by 70+ participants. In June, the project manager promoted FastTrackTech activities and startups at a webinar organised by Smart Tunisia (60+ participants). The project also featured several female entrepreneurs in Africa in an article about how they are dealing with Covid19. The Fast Tracking Digital Entrepreneurship web page on the Intracen website is built and includes a French and English page, startup logos & links, a documents page, a tools page and a news page.

reporting-org.narrative: Asian Development Bank

title.narrative: COVID-19: Systems Strengthening for Effective Coverage of New Vaccines in the Pacific Project under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility (Additional Financing)

description.narrative: The original project adopts a regional approach to improving immunization outcomes by introducing three vaccines in Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. It supports the countries in(i) pooling the procurement of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine, the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV), and the rotavirus vaccine through the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF); (ii) strengthening primary health care and the capacity to deliver vaccination programs; and (iii) increasing community awareness and the population's knowledge of and attitude toward vaccines. The project will reduce the burden and minimize outbreaks related to vaccine-preventable diseases, integrate immunization programs into broader health systems, and improve access to primary health services. As a response to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, the governments of Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu have been preparing for the imminent arrival of COVID-19 vaccines, and have requested additional financing from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to further strengthen immunization programs and prepare for the vaccine rollout.2 The additional financing will build on the original project to support the four governments in meeting their urgent needs.

reporting-org.narrative: Asian Development Bank

title.narrative: COVID-19: Systems Strengthening for Effective Coverage of New Vaccines in the Pacific Project under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility (Additional Financing)

description.narrative: The original project adopts a regional approach to improving immunization outcomes by introducing three vaccines in Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. It supports the countries in(i) pooling the procurement of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine, the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV), and the rotavirus vaccine through the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF); (ii) strengthening primary health care and the capacity to deliver vaccination programs; and (iii) increasing community awareness and the population's knowledge of and attitude toward vaccines. The project will reduce the burden and minimize outbreaks related to vaccine-preventable diseases, integrate immunization programs into broader health systems, and improve access to primary health services. As a response to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, the governments of Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu have been preparing for the imminent arrival of COVID-19 vaccines, and have requested additional financing from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to further strengthen immunization programs and prepare for the vaccine rollout.2 The additional financing will build on the original project to support the four governments in meeting their urgent needs.

reporting-org.narrative: Asian Development Bank

title.narrative: Air Quality Improvement in the Greater Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei Region-Green Financing Scale up Project

description.narrative: The proposed project uses the financial intermediation loan modality, which is the best fit to support geographically scattered investments while maximizing ADB's loan leveraging capacity through revolving the loan fund and mobilizing domestic funds. It aims to address emerging challenges in air quality improvement and GHG emission reduction in both the greater BTH and YRD regions through energy efficiency, cleaner transport systems development, renewable energy development, and cooling systems retrofit. It also stimulates post COVID-19 recovery investment with build-back-better principles by continuously scaling up clean energy technologies and systems applications in the targeted regions, which account for around 50% of the gross domestic product in the PRC. The project will support key strategic pillars of ADB's Strategy 2030: (i) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability by accelerating low greenhouse gas emissions development and ensuring environmental sustainability; (ii) strengthening governance and institutional capacity by providing inclusive financial services for clean energy investment; and (iii) accelerating progress in achieving gender equality through gender mainstreaming activities.

reporting-org.narrative: Asian Development Bank

title.narrative: COVID-19: Emergency Response Project

description.narrative:
ADB will provide a 2-year loan to Jointown to support short-term financing needs, which will help the company to manage its inventory. Increase in short-term funding facilities is crucial if Jointown is to cater to the increased demand while maintaining service delivery standards. The company has committed to protecting the supply of medical goods, ensuring quality, and continuing service during the outbreak.
With its 75,000 square meter distribution warehouse in Wuhan city, the single largest pharmaceutical distribution center in the PRC, Jointown is uniquely placed to meet the demands of addressing the outbreak at its epicenter. In addition to its headquarters operations in Wuhan, Jointown is playing a crucial role in addressing the epidemic in the most affected provinces of the PRC, including Guangdong, Henan, and Hunan.
The COVID-19 outbreak has also overwhelmed the operations of humanitarian organizations such as the Red Cross. Given Jointown's sophisticated warehouse and inventory management systems, it has been asked by the local government to manage the warehouses of the Wuhan Branch and the Hubei Branch of the Red Cross Society of China to classify, store, and manage inventory of donated products. Service standards have since vastly improved, and Jointown will likely be requested to manage emergency storages in other affected provinces.

reporting-org.narrative: Asian Development Bank

title.narrative: COVID-19: Jointown COVID-19 Pharmaceutical Distribution Expansion Project

description.narrative:
THe proceeds of the Asian Development Bank's (ADB's) proposed loan and a loan to be provided by Deutsche Investitions- und Entwicklungsgesellschaft mbH (DEG) will be used to construct and/or expand three pharmaceutical distribution facilities in the PRC provinces of Hainan, Hebei, and Jiangsu, and for Jointown's working capital needs. Jointown is the PRC's fourth largest pharmaceutical distributor and the only private company in the top five.
This project will increase access to more affordable pharmaceutical drugs and medical devices and equipment for the underserved populations of the PRC's tier 2 and 3 cities and rural areas. As part of the broader response of ADB to the needs of its developing member countries (DMCs) during the ongoing coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, the project will also support readiness for pharmaceutical surge capacity if the COVID-19 pandemic resurfaces and intensifies in the PRC.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Emergency Energy Supply Project

description.narrative: The proceeds of this loan will be used to help ensure natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) supplies to households, hospitals, industry and other key services to support business continuity in Wuhan City and Hubei Province amidst the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) epidemic, and post-epidemic recovery. reporting-org.narrative: Asian Development Bank

title.narrative: COVID-19: Second Health System Enhancement to Address and Limit COVID-19 under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility

description.narrative:
The proposed loan to the Republic of the Philippines for the Second Health System Enhancement to Address and Limit COVID-19 under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility (HEAL 2). Under the rapid response component (RRC) of the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility (APVAX), will provide the Government of the Philippines with timely financing for safe and effective vaccine procurement and logistics, based on an agreed list of eligible expenditures. It will supplement the initial support of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to the government's coronavirus disease (COVID-19) response under the Health System Enhancement to Address and Limit COVID-19 (HEAL) project. HEAL 2 is aligned with three operational priorities of ADB's Strategy 2030: (i) addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities; (ii) accelerating progress in gender equality; and (iii) fostering regional cooperation and integration.
The Philippines has met all APVAX access criteria by (i) demonstrating the adverse impact of the COVID-19 pandemic; (ii) completing a needs assessment and a vaccination allocation and prioritization plan, including an incremental medical waste management plan and procurement arrangements acceptable to ADB, with ADB's receipt of a Governor's letter confirming its commitment to implement the plan and ensure compliance with the APVAX vaccine eligibility criteria; and (iii) establishing an effective development partner coordination mechanism with a clear role for ADB

title.narrative: COVID-19: Second Shock-Responsive Social Protection Project

description.narrative: With a worsening coronavirus disease (COVID-19) situation unfolding in the fourth quarter of 2020, the Government of Mongolia has requested urgent additional support for social protection measures to mitigate the socioeconomic impacts of the pandemic on poor and vulnerable groups. The proposed project will (i) apply shock-responsive social protection principles to continue support for pro-poor child grant top-ups on a temporary basis through an established national social assistance program, and (ii) strengthen social welfare programs and systems for improved household resilience and government response to future crises.

reporting-org.narrative: Asian Development Bank

title.narrative: Dairy Farmer Support and Food Security Project

description.narrative: The project will help PT Cisarua Mountain Dairy (CMD) sustain its operations through the COVID-19 crisis by providing financing for working capital and operational expenditure. Due to global logistic disruptions, CMD needs to increase its inventory levels of imported materials to ensure adequate buffers for sustained operations. The US dollar appreciation versus Indonesian rupiah has been weighing on the cost of imported materials, further increasing liquidity needs for building up those inventories. In addition, CMD has started experiencing delayed payments from some of its customers, which have been more severely affected by the crisis. As a result, the cash conversion cycle of the company is expected to increase significantly and cannot be financed from the company's operating cash flow alone. The liquidity support will allow CMD to sustain business operations, enabling stable production and timely payments to farmers, suppliers, employees and sales agents.

reporting-org.narrative: Asian Development Bank

title.narrative: COVID-19: Strengthening Health Security Program (Subprogram 1)

description.narrative: The proposed program aims to strengthen the health sector's response to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic and expedite the medium-term reforms that will strengthen the health system and help Mongolia become better prepared to respond to future health crises. The program's design draws on the operational knowledge that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has gained through its engagement in the health sector in Mongolia since 1993. Through a strategic, coordinated, and well-sequenced set of policy actions, the program will facilitate both immediate and critical medium-term reforms. The provision of a $100 million loan will directly contribute to address the urgent financing needs of the Government of Mongolia. Four reform areas identified under the program will focus on (i) strengthening planning and preparedness of the health sector, and ensuring the availability of critical medicines and emergency supplies; (ii) improving national pharmaceutical regulation, and increasing hospital autonomy and good governance; (iii) enhancing procurement in the health sector to increase efficiency, and establishing a single purchaser for health services; and (iv) safeguarding fiscal sustainability of the government over the medium term (3-5 years).

title.narrative: Emergency Working Capital Support to Dairy Value Chain Project

description.narrative: The transaction involves a loan of up to $10,000,000 to Pran Dairy Limited (PDL). The project will help PDL sustain its operations during the COVID-19 crisis, by providing financing for working capital and operational expenditure. It will enable PDL to step up the procurement of milk and other raw materials and thereby build enough buffer inventory to cope with supply chain disruptions. The liquidity support will also help finance longer accounts receivable periods and advances to farmers, increases in operating expenses, and the continuation of timely payments to farmers, employees, and agents.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Imexpharm COVID-19 Generic Pharmaceutical Project

description.narrative: The proceeds of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) loan and Imexpharm's internal cash accruals will be used to fund Imexpharm's working capital needs amid the global coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic and the resulting economic crisis. The project is an indirect COVID-19 response to address the challenges that arose as a result of supply chain constraints during the COVID-19 pandemic. Pharmaceutical manufacturers such as Imexpharm have had to stockpile inputs amid the supply disruption of pharmaceutical inputs. ADB's funding will be partly utilized for the retroactive financing of capital needs since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic. Imexpharm has so far managed the increased cash needs by negotiating extended payment terms with its suppliers and using internal cash accruals in anticipation of ADB's financing. The proceeds will be used for (i) the purchase of ingredients for pharmaceutical drug manufacturing and (ii) other general working capital needs.

reporting-org.narrative: Asian Development Bank

title.narrative: COVID-19: Tavan Bogd COVID-19 Wheat Supply Chain Liquidity Support Project

description.narrative:
The transaction involves a loan of up to $15,000,000 or its equivalent in togrog, comprising (i) a loan of up to $10,000,000 or its equivalent in togrog to Ulaanbaatar Flour Limited Liability Company (UBF) and (ii) a loan of up to $5,000,000 or its equivalent in togrog to Tavan Bogd Foods Limited Liability Company (TBF) for the Wheat Supply Chain and Food Security Project in Mongolia.
The project will provide essential liquidity support to UBF and TBF so that they can sustain their operations during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) crisis. The project will contribute to food security in Mongolia by ensuring a stable supply of wheat flour, the country's main staple, and flour products. The project will also preserve the livelihood of 4,000 wheat farmers and farm workers, 2,000 employees, and 2,000 sales agents.

title.narrative: Green Loan for Renewable Energy and Electric Vehicle Charging Network

description.narrative: The project entails a corporate loan with a 3-year tenor to support the ongoing renewable energy and sustainable transport activities of Energy Absolute Public Company Limited (Energy Absolute). The loan is expected to be the first green loan in Thailand certified by the Climate Bonds Initiative and only the second in Asia. The assistance of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will support Thailand's renewable energy sector, increase awareness about green loans, and support the transition from a conventional automotive industry to an electric vehicle industry in Thailand by establishing a comprehensive EVCN across Thailand's major cities. ADB's assistance will also support a leading clean energy and sustainable transport company in Thailand at a time when capital markets are still adjusting to the ongoing disruptions caused by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Emergency Response Project

description.narrative:
The proposed project is part of a comprehensive ADB package which also includes budget support for the COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support (CARES) Program. The proposed project will be co-financed by ADB and AIIB to urgently increase Uzbekistan's resilience to COVID-19 pandemics and other epidemics. The project will support the testing, surveillance, and case management of COVID-19 in Uzbekistan by equipping and refurbishing the national laboratory system, establishing an IT-based national surveillance and monitoring system, and improving and expanding the COVID-19 treatment capacity. Activities will be coordinated with, and complementary to, assistance of the World Bank, the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), and fill remaining gaps in medical equipment and supplies.
The proposed project is aligned with four operational priorities of Strategy 2030: (i) addressing poverty and reducing inequalities through improved health access; (ii) accelerating gender equality through occupational safety and training targets for women; (iii) strengthening governance and institutional capacity; and (iv) fostering regional cooperation through reducing risks of cross-border disease transmission. The project further aligns with Uzbekistan's National Actions Strategy for 20172021, and the government-adopted "The Concept of Development of the Healthcare System of the Republic of Uzbekistan for 20192025." Reforms will address systematic health systems issues such as fragmentation, inefficiency, and the insufficient emphasis on non-communicable diseases prevention and early detection.
The project is aligned with (i) concept for the development of the health system of the Republic of Uzbekistan for 20192025, and (ii) the SPRP. The project will have the following outcome: resilience to outbreaks of COVID-19 and other epidemics reinforced. The project will have three outputs: Output 1 - national laboratory system strengthened; Output 2 - national surveillance and response system established for COVID-19 and other epidemics; and Output 3 - COVID-19 treatment capacity expanded.

title.narrative: Recovery through Improved Systems and Expenditure Support Program (Subprogram 1)

description.narrative: The program comprises two subprograms supporting public sector management reforms that will facilitate Palau's recovery from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) crisis. It seeks to strengthen public financial management (PFM), reduce fiscal risks, and support private sector development toward restoring sustained and equitable economic growth. The program will also provide further support for Palau's COVID-19 mitigation measures-initially supported under the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Health Expenditure and Livelihoods Support Program-with the availability of assistance having been extended beyond January 2021 (para. 5). The program is aligned with ADB's Strategy 2030 operational priorities of strengthening governance and institutional capacity, including a differentiated approach to institutional strengthening and private sector development in small island developing states (para. 9), and accelerating progress in gender equality. It is also consistent with the Pacific Approach, 2016-2020 strategic priorities of managing risks by promoting sound public sector management and reducing costs by creating a more enabling business environment, as well as with the proposed Pacific Approach 2021-2025.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Support for COVID-19 Vaccine Delivery in Mongolia under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility

description.narrative:
The risk of continued community spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in Mongolia remains substantial. Since the first case of community transmission was reported on
10 November 2020, several clusters of local transmission have emerged in the capital city and six provinces.
Proposal. The Government of Mongolia officially requested ADB support for securing safe and effective COVID-19 vaccine. The proposed project seeks to provide a loan, through the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility (APVAX) facility, amounting to $40 million to support COVID-19 vaccine delivery in Mongolia.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Vaccine Support Project under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility

description.narrative: The project will provide the Government of Afghanistan with urgently needed and flexible financing for coronavirus disease (COVID-19) vaccine procurement and logistics, and capacity strengthening activities through the APVAX. Afghanistan has met all APVAX access criteria. The project investment component under the APVAX will be utilized. The project will support the implementation of the National Plan for COVID-19 Vaccination in Afghanistan (NPCVA) in line with the fragile and conflict-affected situations (FCAS) approach and Strategy 2030 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).
